oai_dc:dc.dc:title: High strain rate tensile behavior of woven fabric E-glass/epoxy composite
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: NAIK, NK
YERNAMMA, P
THORAM, NM
GADIPATRI, R
KAVALA, VR
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: fiber-reinforced composites
split hopkinson bar
mechanical-behavior
temperature
polymers
strength
composite materials
through the thickness tensile strength
in-plane tensile strength
strain rate effect
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: High strain rate tensile behavior is presented along thickness, warp and fill directions for a typical plain weave fabric E-glass/epoxy composite. Studies were carried out on tensile Split Hopkinson Pressure Bar (SHPB) apparatus in the strain rate range of 140-400/s. For comparison, quasi-static properties were also generated on a universal testing machine. An increase of 75-93% was observed in through the thickness high strain rate tensile strength compared with quasi-static tensile strength. In the range of strain rate considered, as the strain rate was increased, the tensile strength increased up to 11% along the thickness direction. An increase of 63-88% was observed in high strain rate tensile strength along the fill compared with quasi-static tensile strength. In the range of strain rate considered, as the strain rate was increased, the tensile strength increased up to 16% along the fill direction. Since the plain weave fabric used was balanced, the properties along warp and fill are nearly identical. (C) 2009
